title: Is it grammatically correct to write “This is the most true statement I've read in a while”? - Quora

response.answer_text: Is it grammatically correct to write “This is the most true statement I've read in a while”? Yes, it is (you do not need to say ‘truest’). Often ‘more’ and ‘most’ are used for emphasis or clarity, even though grammar says you can use ‘_er’ or ‘_est’ as a suffix on the adjective. However, it is extremely debatable as to whether you should use ‘most’ or ‘_est’ at all. I would not. True and false are binary opposites and do not have degrees of truth or falsity (unless possibly considering multiple statements). A statement is and only can be true or false. There are rules in logic and philosophy that define this better. Just like perfect cannot be more perfect or most perfect. As communicative English does not expect everyone to be logicicans (or even rational), informally and colloquially, we do accept and understand the sentence. Grammar is not subject to sentential logic, but you would be wise to use both good logic and good grammar if you are in a formal situation, especially in an argument or debate.

No,it isn't correct. What made your sentence grammatically incorrect is the incorrect adjective form. It is true that ‘true’ is an adjective, noun and adverb. When we use ‘true’ as an adjective, the sentence must not be in the superlative or comparative context.You can't correctly say “the most true politician” or “ the more true report” .In such contexts the correct adjective form is ‘truthful’. Nevertheless, you can use the superlative or comparative form of true by itself, e.g. “the truest story” or “truer version of the story”. The correct way to construct your sentence is this: “This is the most truthful statement I've read in a while” I hope this helps.
